Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: An individual arrives at the church in a state of acute emotional distress seeking immediate spiritual support for a crisis.
Story:
I was just locking up the church office when Mark, an old acquaintance from college, waved me down in the parking lot. “Hey! You know this area better than anyone—can you recommend a good place to eat nearby?” he asked, his tone light and expectant. I smiled, ready to help, when I noticed a woman hurrying up the church steps, her face streaked with tears. She looked lost, desperate, and I could sense she needed more than directions or a friendly chat—she needed spiritual comfort, right now.

Mark was still waiting, his eyes hopeful, and I could feel the weight of his simple request. At the same time, the woman’s pain pulled at my heart, reminding me of my calling to offer solace and guidance. I stood there, torn, the expectations of friendship and priesthood colliding inside me. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety rising as I tried to figure out how to be both a supportive acquaintance and a compassionate priest in this single, impossible moment.
